qas.question: How does Whitehead view the relationship between God an the world?

answers.text: Whitehead thus sees God and the world as fulfilling one another

qas.question: How does he define entities' need for God?

answers.text: He sees entities in the world as fluent and changing things that yearn for a permanence which only God can provide

qas.question: How dis Whitehead believe God provided permanence to entities?

answers.text: by taking them into God's self, thereafter changing God and affecting the rest of the universe throughout time

qas.question: In what way did Whitehead view God as deficient?
What did Whitehead claim God would be without the world?

plausible_answers.text: He sees entities in the world as fluent and changing things that yearn for a permanence which only God can provide

qas.question: How does he define entities' lack of God?

plausible_answers.text: by taking them into God's self, thereafter changing God and affecting the rest of the universe throughout time

qas.question: How dis Whitehead believe God provided impermanence to entities?
What did Whitehead claim God would be with the world?

context: <a0_0>Whitehead thus sees God and the world as fulfilling one another<a0_0/>. <a1_0><b5_0>He sees entities in the world as fluent and changing things that yearn for a permanence which only God can provide<b5_0/><a1_0/> <a2_0><b6_0>by taking them into God's self, thereafter changing God and affecting the rest of the universe throughout time<b6_0/><a2_0/>. On the other hand, he sees God as permanent but as <a3_0>deficient in actuality and change<a3_0/>: alone, God is <a4_0>merely <b7_0>eternally unrealized possibilities<b7_0/><a4_0/>, and requires the world to actualize them. God gives creatures permanence, while the creatures give God actuality and change. Here it is worthwhile to quote Whitehead at length:
